   ATTENTION EDITORS: The following photos are part of tonight's
New York Times Photo Package, moving Thursday, 07/01/99. Photo
clients will automatically receive these photos via AP's
PhotoExpress or may download them from either the Wieck Photo
Database in Dallas at 972-392-0888 or from NYTPhotos on Newscom at
305-448-8411. Non-clients can make individual purchases by calling
(888) 603-1036 or 212-556-4204.

   (NYT37) WASHINGTON -- July 1, 1999 -- EGYPT-U.S., 7-01 --
President Bill Clinton and Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak leave a
joint press conference on Thursday. Clinton told reporters that the
time was ripe for new approaches to achieving Middle East peace,
but added he did not want to discuss them before he met Israeli
Prime Minister-elect Ehud Barak. (Justin Lane/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT36) PRIZREN, Yugoslavia -- July 1, 1999 -- KOSOVO-SERBIA-3,
7-01 -- Ethnic Albanians wave an Albanian flag as they celebrate
the arrival of NATO troops to Prizren, Kosovo's second largest
city, last month. After three months and tens of thousands of NATO
sorties, Serbian President Slobodan Milosevic's vision of a Greater
Serbia is dead. (Stephen Crowley/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT35) NEW MARKET, Virg. -- July 1, 1999 -- ADV. FOR JULY 4 --
BBO-BASEBALL-VALLEY-COX-2, 7-01 -- Billy Collins, a catcher with
the New Market Rebels, talks to some fans during a game last month.
Young admirers usually gather near the the third base dugout to
talk with their favorite players. For the college players who have
come for 37 summers, the dusty diamonds of the Shenandoah Valley
League are fields of dreams. (Bernie Boston/Cox News Service)

   (NYT34) NEW MARKET, Virg. -- July 1, 1999 -- ADV. FOR JULY 4 --
BBO-BASEBALL-VALLEY-COX-1, 7-01 -- Members of the ``Grandstand
Managers Club,'' take in a game last month. Club members pay $75 a
year to sit in the green seats behind home plate which not only
gives them a good view of the game but also allows them to sit in
close proximity to the umpire who is with in earshot distance of
their complaints. (Bernie Boston/Cox News Service)

   (NYT33) PHOENIX -- July 1, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., JULY 4 --
CLINTON-MARKETS-COX-5, 7-01 -- Gail Knight, executive director of
the Community Excellence Project, stands before a drawing of the
proposed ``Four Corners'' development, a project that city planners
believe is the key to the economic revitalization of south Phoenix.
``This is the way it's supposed to work _ not just government but a
public and private partnership,'' she says. (Rick McKay/Cox
Newspapers Photo)

   (NYT32) PHOENIX -- July 1, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., JULY 4 --
CLINTON-MARKETS-COX-4, 7-01 -- A patient is reflected in the
glasses of dentist Richard Landgren, or ``Dr. Rick,'' as he is
known to the kids at the I.G. Homes Boys and Girls Club, where he
provides virtually free care to 10 children a day, four days a
week. ``Could I be a millionaire somewhere else? Probably,'' says
Landgren. ``Can I make a difference here? Absolutely. But there's a
whole conglomeration of people here who are dedicated to making a
difference.'' (Rick McKay/Cox Newspapers Photo)

   (NYT31) PHOENIX -- July 1, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., JULY 4 --
CLINTON-MARKETS-COX-3, 7-01 -- ``I started out with a $100 bill in
my pocket'' says Leonard Moreno, standing in the 108-degree heat of
the dusty back lot of Moreno Welding, the business he started 20
years ago in this worn-down industrial area of Phoenix. Moreno
Welding grosses nearly $2 million a year and employs between 15 and
20 workers who make between $14 and $20 an hour. (Rick McKay/Cox
Newspapers Photo)

   (NYT30) PHOENIX -- July 1, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., JULY 4 --
CLINTON-MARKETS-COX-2, 7-01 -- By the time President Clinton gets
to Phoenix this week, the abandoned Rainbow Market, an adjoining
deserted liquor store and Wong's To Go Chinese Food will be gone.
The market, liquor store and carry-out are the last remains of the
city's most notorious intersection, 24th and Broadway, long a haunt
of drug dealers, crackheads, speakeasies and prostitutes. (Rick
McKay/Cox Newspapers Photo)

   (NYT29) PHOENIX -- July 1, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., JULY 4 --
CLINTON-MARKETS-COX-1, 7-01 -- No city in America has experienced
greater sustained growth than Phoenix, which has expanded from less
than 6,000 in 1900 to 1.2 million today. But despite its
travel-brochure image of swaying palms and lush golf courses, some
areas are anything but an oasis. Crime, unemployment and poverty
are pervasive, especially in south Phoenix (foreground). (Rick
McKay/Cox Newspapers Photo)

   (NYT28) WACO, Texas -- July 1, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., JULY 4 --
SUMMER-SCHOOL-COX-2, 7-01 -- Erik Ramirez of Waco, an honor roll
student whose test anxiety led to six weeks of mandatory summer
school last year before his promotion to to fourth grade. This
year, Erik passed his promotion test to fifth grade on the first
try with the help of his teacher, Sherry Johnson. (Kelly
Lemons/Waco Tribune Herald Photo)

   (NYT27) WASHINGTON -- July 1, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., JULY 4 --
SUMMER-SCHOOL-COX-1, 7-01 -- ``I don't know what I want to do when
I am older and go to college, and summer gives me a chance to pick
up different ideas,'' says Alex Ridder, a junior at Kent Denver
High School in Colorado. As part of a one-week course in
environmental journalism, he paddled a canoe past dead fish
floating on the Anacostia River after a summer storm flushed raw
sewage into storm drains in Washington, D.C. (Rick McKay/Cox
Newspapers Photo)

   (NYT26) PRISTINA, Yugoslavia -- July 1, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN.,
JULY 4 --KOSOVO-CIVIL-COX-2, 7-01 -- Ethnic Albanian Jakup Mehmeti,
37, lost his job installing stoplights after the Serbs took over
local government in Kosovo in 1989. When NATO troops took over
governing duties two weeks ago, Mehmeti reported to his old
municipality and volunteered to get the lights working again. NATO
officials gave him two to strap onto his Opel and take to the
streets. (Larry Kaplow/Cox Newspapers Photo)

   (NYT25) PRISTINA, Yugoslavia -- July 1, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN.,
JULY 4 --KOSOVO-CIVIL-COX-1, 7-01 -- Selim Gravalla, 34, left, had
his house burned and the inventory of his building company stolen
by Serbs; Abedin Kadriu, 62, right, had his tractor stolen. The
ethnic Albanians are shown waiting for hours to report the crimes
to British military police in their temporary police station in
Pristina. (Larry Kaplow/Cox Newspapers Photo)

   (NYT24) GAZA CITY -- July 1, 1999 -- GAZA-SETTLEMENTS, 7-01 --
Palestinian workers wait to have their identity papers checked
before returning to their homes in Gaza. Most of the Palestinians
waiting in line work at construction sites in Jewish settlements
near Gaza and on the West Bank. An estimated 11,000 Palestinians
work in Jewish settlements in the West Bank and Gaza Strip,
building the very communities that Palestinian leaders have called
a cancer strangling prospects for an independent Palestinian state.
(Rina Castelnuovo/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT23) WASHINGTON -- July 1, 1999 -- EVERGLADES-COX, 7-01 --
Flanked by members of Congress, Vice President Al Gore announces a
restoration plan for the Florida Everglades during a news
conference Thursday on Capitol Hill. Legislators from left, Rep.
Sherwood Boehlert, R-NY, Rep. Mark Foley, R-Fla., Sen. Bob Graham,
D-Fla., and Sen. Connie Mack, R-Fla. (Rick McKay/Cox News Service)

   (NYT22) EVANSTON, Ill. -- July 1, 1999 -- LIQUIDITY-TRAP, 7-01
-- Robert J. Gordon, a Northwestern University economist, at his
home in Evanston. In last-minute revisions to the latest edition of
his textbook for undergraduate economics majors, he is upgrading
the discussion of the resistant consumer from a single, skeptical
footnote to a respectful discussion. ``When you go 50 years without
a phenomenon being relevant, it dies out of the curriculum,'' he
says. ``Now it's relevant again.'' (Steve Kagan/New York Times
Photo)

   (NYT21) NEW YORK -- July 1, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., JULY 4 --
MUTFUND-STRATEGY, 7-01 -- Samuel Eisenstadt, research chairman of
Value Line. ``Some of the 100 Group 1 stocks have small market
caps, and we couldn't buy them without driving the market for them
crazy,'' says Eisenstadt, referring to the newsletter's top-ranked
stocks. (Andrea Mohin/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT20) BRIGHTON, Mich. -- July 1, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., JULY 4
-- ABOUT-MOTOR-HOMES-3, 7-01 -- One can expand the 38-foot-long,
$250,000 Fleetwood American Eagle with a button, not with an
architect. It takes a lot of space to accommodate all of the
amenities of this rolling road house. (Peter Yates/New York Times
Photo)

   (NYT19) BRIGHTON, Mich. -- July 1, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., JULY 4
-- ABOUT-MOTOR-HOMES-2, 7-01 -- The 38-foot-long, $250,000
Fleetwood American Eagle has leather, marble and a full kitchen for
relaxing, which is appreciated after some nervous time at the
wheel. A vehicle like this provides most of the creature comforts
of a suburban home even as one attempts to commune with nature.
(Peter Yates/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT18) BRIGHTON, Mich. -- July 1, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., JULY 4
-- ABOUT-MOTOR-HOMES-1, 7-01 -- Roughing it in the 38-foot-long,
$250,000 Fleetwood American Eagle? No way. A shower, right, will be
handy; and you can just drive right past the local laundry. (Peter
Yates/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT17) UNDATED -- July 1, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., JULY 4 --
MUTFUND-JUNKBONDS-B&W, 7-01 -- Thomas Soviero, manager of Fidelity
High Income, says that in a market afraid of a rise in defaults,
opportunities can be found. Indeed, he says, the market nervousness
creates opportunities to find bonds that others may overlook. ``We
should be able to avoid those defaults and find the pearls,'' he
says. (New York Times Photo)

   (NYT16) NEW YORK -- July 1, 1999 -- BROCHTRUP-THEATER, 7-01 --
Polly Draper, an alumna of ``Thirtysomething,'' has taken over the
role of Anna in ``Closer.'' Her portrayal taps nicely into an
intensifying current in New York theater: the deployment of actors
more familiar from the pages of TV Guide than Playbill, in
productions across the city and beyond. (Sara Krulwich/New York
Times Photo)

   (NYT15) PORTLAND, Ore. -- July 1, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., JULY 4
-- MUTFUND-MANAGERS-3, 7-01 -- Jim Crabbe had positioned the
Liberty-Crabbe Huson Special fund to profit when
small-capitalization stocks regained the market's favor. ``The
market is going through a rotational correction,'' says Crabbe, 54.
``Some parts of the market are still very overpriced, but there are
some tremendously good bargains, particularly among smaller
companies.'' (John Gress/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT14) NEW YORK -- July 1, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., JULY 4 --
MUTFUND-MANAGERS-2, 7-01 -- Robert J. Martorelli says expansion in
the American economy and recovery abroad have helped the cyclical
industrial stocks in his Merrill Lynch Phoenix fund. He expects
such value stocks to keep climbing. (Chester Higgins Jr./New York
Times Photo)

   (NYT13) NEW YORK -- July 1, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., JULY 4 --
MUTFUND-MANAGERS, 7-01 -- After a long dry spell in which the
stock-market boom seemed to pass them by, value stocks and shares
of small- to mid-capitalization companies came into their own in
the second quarter. Dennis Delafield, right, and Vincent
Sellecchia, co-managers, reaped some of the benefits in the
Delafield fund. (Ozier Muhammad/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT12) WASHINGTON -- July 1, 1999 -- KOSOVO-MILITARY, 7-01 --
NATO's military commander, Gen. Wesley K. Clark, testifies before
the Senate Armed Services Committee on Thursday. It was his first
appearance before Congress since before the air campaign over
Yugoslavia. (Shana Raab/New York Times Photo) LITE

   (NYT11) NEW YORK -- July 1, 1999 -- SHREW-THEATER-REVIEW, 7-01
-- Allison Janney and Jay O. Sanders battle in the Central Park
``The Taming of The Shrew.'' They writhe and they whoop it up,
trade punches, prance, dance, screech, shriek, croon, caterwaul and
do cartwheels. All this seems entirely apropos. Although the
direction is credited to Mel Shapiro, this ``Shrew'' might indeed
have been put on the card by Vince McMahon of the World Wrestling
Federation. (Sara Krulwich/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT10) STRASBURG, Pa. -- July 1, 1999 -- STEAM-TRAIN-2, 7-01 --
Tourists exploring the historic town of Strasburg. The town is home
to the Strasburg Rail Road, the nation's oldest short-line
railroad. Founded in 1832, it became a tourist operation in 1958.
(Laura Pedrick/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT9) STRASBURG, Pa. -- July 1, 1999 -- STEAM-TRAIN-3, 7-01 --
Young train enthusiasts greeting the arrival of a steam engine at
the East Strasburg Station in Pennsylvania. Founded in 1832, the
nation's oldest short-line railroad became a tourist operation in
1958. Today the line has four fearsomely voracious steam engines,
consuming 1,000 gallons of water and a half-ton of hand-shoveled
coal per mile, and 14 restored wooden coaches, each with its own
19th-century decor and degree of comfort. (Laura Pedrick/New York
Times Photo) LITE

   (NYT8) STRASBURG, Pa. -- July 1, 1999 -- STEAM-TRAIN-1, 7-01 --
A 19th-century flavor abounds in Strasburg, where Amish buggies and
antique steam trains bisect the farmland. Though pastoral, the area
is also command central for railroad buffs, being home to one of
the oldest operating steam rail lines in America, a magnificent
railroad museum next door and enough toy trains to occupy even the
most fidgety enthusiast, of any age. (Laura Pedrick/New York Times
Photo)

   (NYT7) NEW YORK -- July 1, 1999 -- THEATER-NOTES, 7-01 -- Anna
Deavere Smith will bring ``House Arrest'' to the Public in March.
The first viewing of ``House Arrest'' was in late 1997 at the Arena
Stage in Washington. But a month later Monicagate began, prompting
Ms. Smith to pull the piece from planned performances in Los
Angeles and Seattle, to enlarge President Clinton's role. ``I love
performing him,'' she says. ``He does these astonishing linguistic
things.'' (Sara Krulwich/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT6) PEC, Yugoslavia -- July 1, 1999 -- DEATH-SQUAD-BOS, 7-01
-- Lirie Gashi holds a portrait of her brother-in-law Ahmet Gashi
in front of the house where he was gunned down along with 14
others, allegedly by Serb forces. Documents obtained by The Globe
begin to paint a picture of how Pec's local Serb paramilitary units
operated in concert with the Yugoslave Ministry of Interior Police,
known as ``MUPs,'' and with special units within the Yugoslav army.
(Bill Greene/Boston Globe Photo)

   (NYT5) ASHEVILLE, N.C. -- July 1, 1999 -- TRAVEL-BILTMORE-COX,
7-01 -- The The renovated Morland room at the Biltmore Estate. Four
newly restored bedrooms on the third floor of Asheville's
circa-1895 Biltmore Estate are included in the tour of George
Vanderbilt's grand chateau in the Blue Ridge Mountains.
Collectively known as the Artists' Suite, the rooms' names -
Watson, Van Dyck, Morland, and Madonna - allude to artists and
works represented in Vanderbilt's collection. (Biltmore Estate/Cox
News Service)

   (NYT4) PEC, Yugoslavia -- July 1, 1999 -- KOSOVO-SERBIA-2, 7-01
-- Ethnic Albanians rummage through the belongings of Serbs,
including a religious icon, which were trhown into an alley earlier
this week. Pec was once a beautiful town, threaded by bright
streams, backed by mountains. Like Mostar in Bosnia, and all that
was most lovely in the Balkans, it expressed the delicate
interweaving of Islamic and Christian architecture and traditions
that was the legacy of the Ottoman Empire. (Stephen Crowley/New
York Times Photo)

   (NYT3) KOSOVO POLJE, Yugoslavia -- July 1, 1999 --
KOSOVO-SERBIA, 7-01 -- A truck drives past the town sign covered
with Serb graffiti earlier this week. The destruction inflicted by
tens of thousands of NATO sorties is evident in this ragged central
Kosovo town. A decade after Serbian President Slobodan Milosevic
whipped up Serb nationalism in a speech here, the notion of Greater
Serbia is dead. (Stephen Crowley/New York Times Photo) LITE

   (NYT2) MODENA, Italy -- July 01, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., JULY 4
-- DAYS-BEFORE-THEATER-2, 7-01 -- A scene from ``The Days Before:
Death, Destruction and Detroit III,'' opening at Lincoln Center,
directed by Robert Wilson. ``The most touching thing about the
piece are the moments when I see who you are as individuals,'' says
Wilson, 57. ``Sometimes you're trying to act what's in your head,
and then I don't believe you. But if you feel something, that's
truth, it's your experience.'' (James Hill/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT1) MODENA, Italy -- July 01, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., JULY 4
-- DAYS-BEFORE-THEATER-1, 7-01 -- Robert Wilson seated on a chair
of his design at the Teatro Communale in Modena, where his latest
work, ``The Days Before: Death, Destruction and Detroit III,'' was
in rehearsals last month. ``If I had studied theater, I would never
make the work I do,'' says Wilson, 57. (James Hill/New York Times
Photo) LITE

   The New York Times News Service

should be able to avoid those defaults and find the pearls,'' he
says. (New York Times Photo)

   (NYT16) NEW YORK -- July 1, 1999 -- BROCHTRUP-THEATER, 7-01 --
Polly Draper, an alumna of ``Thirtysomething,'' has taken over the
role of Anna in ``Closer.'' Her portrayal taps nicely into an
intensifying current in New York theater: the deployment of actors
more familiar from the pages of TV Guide than Playbill, in
productions across the city and beyond. (Sara Krulwich/New York
Times Photo)

   (NYT15) PORTLAND, Ore. -- July 1, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., JULY 4
-- MUTFUND-MANAGERS-3, 7-01 -- Jim Crabbe had positioned the
Liberty-Crabbe Huson Special fund to profit when
small-capitalization stocks regained the market's favor. ``The
market is going through a rotational correction,'' says Crabbe, 54.
``Some parts of the market are still very overpriced, but there are
some tremendously good bargains, particularly among smaller
companies.'' (John Gress/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT14) NEW YORK -- July 1, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., JULY 4 --
MUTFUND-MANAGERS-2, 7-01 -- Robert J. Martorelli says expansion in
the American economy and recovery abroad have helped the cyclical
industrial stocks in his Merrill Lynch Phoenix fund. He expects
such value stocks to keep climbing. (Chester Higgins Jr./New York
Times Photo)

   (NYT13) NEW YORK -- July 1, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., JULY 4 --
MUTFUND-MANAGERS, 7-01 -- After a long dry spell in which the
stock-market boom seemed to pass them by, value stocks and shares
of small- to mid-capitalization companies came into their own in
the second quarter. Dennis Delafield, right, and Vincent
Sellecchia, co-managers, reaped some of the benefits in the
Delafield fund. (Ozier Muhammad/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT12) WASHINGTON -- July 1, 1999 -- KOSOVO-MILITARY, 7-01 --
NATO's military commander, Gen. Wesley K. Clark, testifies before
the Senate Armed Services Committee on Thursday. It was his first
appearance before Congress since before the air campaign over
Yugoslavia. (Shana Raab/New York Times Photo) LITE

   (NYT11) NEW YORK -- July 1, 1999 -- SHREW-THEATER-REVIEW, 7-01
-- Allison Janney and Jay O. Sanders battle in the Central Park
``The Taming of The Shrew.'' They writhe and they whoop it up,
trade punches, prance, dance, screech, shriek, croon, caterwaul and
do cartwheels. All this seems entirely apropos. Although the
direction is credited to Mel Shapiro, this ``Shrew'' might indeed
have been put on the card by Vince McMahon of the World Wrestling
Federation. (Sara Krulwich/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT10) STRASBURG, Pa. -- July 1, 1999 -- STEAM-TRAIN-2, 7-01 --
Tourists exploring the historic town of Strasburg. The town is home
to the Strasburg Rail Road, the nation's oldest short-line
railroad. Founded in 1832, it became a tourist operation in 1958.
(Laura Pedrick/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT9) STRASBURG, Pa. -- July 1, 1999 -- STEAM-TRAIN-3, 7-01 --
Young train enthusiasts greeting the arrival of a steam engine at
the East Strasburg Station in Pennsylvania. Founded in 1832, the
nation's oldest short-line railroad became a tourist operation in
1958. Today the line has four fearsomely voracious steam engines,
consuming 1,000 gallons of water and a half-ton of hand-shoveled
coal per mile, and 14 restored wooden coaches, each with its own
19th-century decor and degree of comfort. (Laura Pedrick/New York
Times Photo) LITE

   (NYT8) STRASBURG, Pa. -- July 1, 1999 -- STEAM-TRAIN-1, 7-01 --
A 19th-century flavor abounds in Strasburg, where Amish buggies and
antique steam trains bisect the farmland. Though pastoral, the area
is also command central for railroad buffs, being home to one of
the oldest operating steam rail lines in America, a magnificent
railroad museum next door and enough toy trains to occupy even the
most fidgety enthusiast, of any age. (Laura Pedrick/New York Times
Photo)

   (NYT7) NEW YORK -- July 1, 1999 -- THEATER-NOTES, 7-01 -- Anna
Deavere Smith will bring ``House Arrest'' to the Public in March.
The first viewing of ``House Arrest'' was in late 1997 at the Arena
Stage in Washington. But a month later Monicagate began, prompting
Ms. Smith to pull the piece from planned performances in Los
Angeles and Seattle, to enlarge President Clinton's role. ``I love
performing him,'' she says. ``He does these astonishing linguistic
things.'' (Sara Krulwich/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT6) PEC, Yugoslavia -- July 1, 1999 -- DEATH-SQUAD-BOS, 7-01
-- Lirie Gashi holds a portrait of her brother-in-law Ahmet Gashi
in front of the house where he was gunned down along with 14
others, allegedly by Serb forces. Documents obtained by The Globe
begin to paint a picture of how Pec's local Serb paramilitary units
operated in concert with the Yugoslave Ministry of Interior Police,
known as ``MUPs,'' and with special units within the Yugoslav army.
(Bill Greene/Boston Globe Photo)

   (NYT5) ASHEVILLE, N.C. -- July 1, 1999 -- TRAVEL-BILTMORE-COX,
7-01 -- The The renovated Morland room at the Biltmore Estate. Four
newly restored bedrooms on the third floor of Asheville's
circa-1895 Biltmore Estate are included in the tour of George
Vanderbilt's grand chateau in the Blue Ridge Mountains.
Collectively known as the Artists' Suite, the rooms' names -
Watson, Van Dyck, Morland, and Madonna - allude to artists and
works represented in Vanderbilt's collection. (Biltmore Estate/Cox
News Service)

   (NYT4) PEC, Yugoslavia -- July 1, 1999 -- KOSOVO-SERBIA-2, 7-01
-- Ethnic Albanians rummage through the belongings of Serbs,
including a religious icon, which were trhown into an alley earlier
this week. Pec was once a beautiful town, threaded by bright
streams, backed by mountains. Like Mostar in Bosnia, and all that
was most lovely in the Balkans, it expressed the delicate
interweaving of Islamic and Christian architecture and traditions
that was the legacy of the Ottoman Empire. (Stephen Crowley/New
York Times Photo)

   (NYT3) KOSOVO POLJE, Yugoslavia -- July 1, 1999 --
KOSOVO-SERBIA, 7-01 -- A truck drives past the town sign covered
with Serb graffiti earlier this week. The destruction inflicted by
tens of thousands of NATO sorties is evident in this ragged central
Kosovo town. A decade after Serbian President Slobodan Milosevic
whipped up Serb nationalism in a speech here, the notion of Greater
Serbia is dead. (Stephen Crowley/New York Times Photo) LITE

piece are the moments when I see who you are as individuals,'' says

   (NYT1) MODENA, Italy -- July 01, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., JULY 4

of his design at the Teatro Communale in Modena, where his latest
work, ``The Days Before: Death, Destruction and Detroit III,'' was
